questions.text: Match the following CT images:
questions.solution:
Pons is identified by looking at bridge like pattern (pons is a Latin word for bridge)

KEY TAKE AWAY:

questions.text: Identify the sequence of the MRI shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) is a valuable noninvasive diagnostic tool for assessing the neuraxis, including the brain and spine. By utilizing nonionizing electromagnetic radiation, MRI avoids the risks associated with ionizing radiation found in other imaging modalities, such as X-rays and CT scans.

FLAIR (Fluid-Attenuated Inversion Recovery) - a special type of T2-weighted sequence that suppresses the cerebrospinal fluid signal, which allows for better visualization of certain pathological changes near to ventricles.

DWI (Diffusion Weighted Imaging) - this sequence allows imaging of water diffusion processes in tissues. It is particularly useful in detecting early signs of stroke.

SWI (Susceptibility Weighted Imaging) - enhances the visualization of blood products, especially useful in Diffuse axonal injury.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: Identify the sequence of MRI shown in the image below:
questions.solution: KEY TAKE AWAY:

questions.text: A patient presented with altered sensorium and headache. He went to a neuro physician who after examining advised him to undergo a non-contrast CT scan which is shown below. What is the most probable cause for the imaging finding given below?
questions.solution:
Image shows "star of death" appearance, suggestive of subarachnoid, hemorrhage

SUBARACHNOID HEMORRHAGE (SAH)

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Most common site of aneurysm rupture in SAH is ACOM followed by MCA aneurysm.

questions.text: An elderly hypertensive patient came with a history of fall, following which he is confused, lethargic, disoriented and unable to speak properly. He was advised to undergo a CT scan of the head which is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
KEY TAKE AWAY:

Extradural hemorrhage is biconvex in shape

Intraparenchymal hemorrhage is noted in the brain parenchyma

Subarachnoid hemorrhage is seen in basal cisterns.

Subdural hemorrhage is concavo-convex / crescentic / banana in shape.

NOTE:

EDH usually occurs with forceful impact injury like road traffic accidents in young.

SDH usually occurs with trivial injury seen in elderly population.

questions.text: A patient presented with blurring of vision and difficulty of speech. On the basis of the symptoms, it was considered as a stroke and thrombolysis was being considered. What investigation should be done before starting the thrombolytics?
questions.solution:
KEY TAKE AWAY:

NCCT is the first investigation to be done in a suspected case of stroke to rule out hemorrhagic stroke.

Absolute contraindications for thrombolysis:

questions.text:
A patient presented with blurring of vision and difficulty of speech. On the basis of the symptoms, it was considered as a stroke. Which of the following investigations are included in stroke protocol?
1. NCCT head
2. CT angiography
3. MRI brain
4. MRI contrast angiography
questions.solution:
Stroke is a sudden onset of neurological deficit due to cerebrovascular disease.

Initial Imaging:

  • Non-contrast Head CT: First-line imaging to rule out hemorrhage or mass lesions, crucial for treatment decisions.

Advanced Imaging:

  • CT Angiography (CTA): Standard for assessing large vessel occlusion (LVO).
  • CT Perfusion: Useful for evaluating large vessel ischemia, can be qualitative or quantitative.

MRI Role:

  • Diffusion-Weighted Imaging (DWI): Critical for detecting acute ischemia when CT findings are inconclusive. DWI is the reference standard for measuring core infarct volume.
  • Perfusion-Weighted Imaging (PWI): Assists in therapy guidance when available, especially for posterior fossa or brainstem lesions.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Treatment Windows:

  • 4.5 to 6 hours: Timeframe for potential intervention in non-hemorrhagic ischemic stroke.
  • Initial CT is the preferred study within 6 hours of symptom onset.
  • CTA or MRI (DWI and PWI) is used between 4.5 and 6 hours to assess endovascular treatment eligibility.

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of unilateral weakness and difficulty in speech. He was advised to undergo a CT scan of the head which is shown below. What is shown in the image?
questions.solution:
1. Dense Artery Sign: Visible on CT as early as the onset of the stroke, indicating fresh thrombus in the vessel.
    • Proximal MCA or Terminal ICA: Associated with larger infarcts and poorer outcomes.
    • MCA Branch (Sylvian Fissure Dot Sign): If limited to a branch, the prognosis may be better.
  2. Basilar Artery: Can also show density changes in cases of posterior circulation infarcts, particularly with "top of basilar" syndrome.
  3. Early Parenchymal Changes: Include reduced grey matter density and brain swelling, which may be seen as effacement of sulci referred to as insular ribbon sign.

These findings are crucial for early diagnosis and management of stroke patients.

MCA dot sign

Loss of insular ribbon - sign of early MCA infarction

KEY TAKE AWAY:

questions.text:
A patient presented with fever and altered sensorium. A diagnosis of cranial infection was considered. On doing a contrast MRI scan the following image was obtained.

The MRI showed a ring enhancing lesion in the brain parenchyma. Which of the following is not a differential of ring enhancing lesion?
questions.solution:
A ring-enhancing lesion is an imaging finding characterized by a peripheral rim of enhancement surrounding a central area that may be hypoattenuating or non-enhancing.

Differential Diagnosis

  1. Infectious Causes
    • Abscesses:
      • Bacterial: Commonly found in the brain; may be due to infections like pyogenic abscesses.
      • Tuberculomas: Associated with tuberculosis, often presenting with a central caseous necrosis.
      • Fungal: Such as in cryptococcal infections, particularly in immunocompromised patients.
  2. Neoplastic Causes
    • Primary Brain Tumors:
      • Glioblastoma Multiforme: Typically shows a necrotic center with surrounding edema.
      • Metastatic Lesions: Commonly ring-enhancing due to necrosis or edema, especially from lung or breast cancer.
    • Lymphoma: Especially in immunocompromised patients, can present as a solitary ring-enhancing lesion.
  3. Vascular Causes
    • Cerebral Infarcts: Can have a ring-enhancing appearance, especially in subacute stages.
    • Hemorrhagic Transformation: Post-infarction or post-surgical hematomas may appear as ring-enhancing lesions.
  4. Other Causes
    • Demyelinating Diseases: Such as multiple sclerosis, can present with ring-enhancing lesions.
    • Granulomatous Diseases: Conditions like sarcoidosis can also appear as ring-enhancing lesions.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

RING ENHANCING LESIONS

Meningioma (Dural tail sign)

questions.text: A patient had a history of fever and diarrhea. After some days he developed flaccid paralysis. The physician ordered a contrast MRI of the patient which is shown below. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the rapid onset of muscle weakness and paralysis due to the immune system attacking the peripheral nerves. It affects sensory, motor, and autonomic nerves and is the most common cause of rapidly progressive flaccid paralysis.

Etiology and Preceding Infections

  • Most cases are preceded by infections, commonly upper respiratory or gastrointestinal, with Campylobacter jejuni being the most frequent pathogen identified.

Radiological Studies

  • MRI is utilized to exclude other conditions such as transverse myelitis and compressive polyradiculopathy when nerve conduction studies and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) examinations are inconclusive.

MRI Findings

  1. Contrast Administration:
    • It is crucial to use contrast agents, as non-contrast MRI sequences are typically normal in GBS.
  2. Typical MRI Findings:
    • Thickening and Contrast Enhancement
    • In the brain, the facial nerve (CN VII) is most commonly affected and may show enhancement or edema on MRI.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Acute onset of flaccid paralysis with the history of recent infection, like diarrhea along with thickening and contrast enhancement on MRI suggest GBS.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option A: Multiple myeloma appears on an MRI as a round, low signal intensity focus on T1-weighted images, and high signal intensity on T2-weighted images, because myeloma lesions have lower fat content and higher cellularity & water content than muscle and intervertebral discs.

T1 image

Option B: Multiple sclerosis on MRI seen as hyperintense lesions at periventricular region (yellow arrows) and a short segment lesion at T6 level of the spinal cord (blue arrow).

Option D: Sub Acute Combined Degeneration (SACD) occurs due to deficiency of vitamin B12. Clinical findings are symmetrical and occur due to the involvement of the dorsal columns, spinocerebellar tracts, and lateral corticospinal tracts.

questions.text: A patient presented with dementia, seizures and frequent history of falls. On doing an MRI scan, the following image was obtained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CAA is Ischemic Microangiopathy: The most common cause of small vessel disease.

  • Risk Factors:
    • Age
    • Hypertension
    • Diabetes Mellitus
    • Hyperlipidemia
    • Smoking
  • Affected Areas on MRI:
    • Periventricular and deep cerebral white matter
    • Basal ganglia
    • Thalami
    • Ventral pons

Pathophysiology

  • Vessel Occlusion:
    • Larger perforating vessels: Lead to lacunar infarcts.
    • Smaller arterioles: Result in ischemic demyelination and gliosis.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Chronic amyloid angiopathy shows peripheral distribution of the hemorrhages.
  • Toxic leukoencephalopathy shows white matter changes.
  • Alcohol poisoning also affects the white matter.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child came with complaints of seizures and difficulty in walking and delayed developmental milestones. He underwent an MRI examination which is shown below. What is not associated with the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Dandy-Walker malformation is indeed a significant posterior fossa malformation characterized by distinct features.

Key Features of Dandy-Walker Malformation

  1. Cystic Dilatation of the Fourth Ventricle: This is a hallmark of the condition.
  2. Enlarged Posterior Fossa: The posterior fossa is enlarged, often leading to elevated venous confluence (torcula) above the lambdoid suture.
  3. Cerebellar Vermis: There is either aplasia (absence) or hypoplasia (underdevelopment) of the cerebellar vermis, with rotation of the vermis.
  4. Associated Conditions:
    • Hydrocephalus: Increased cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) accumulation can occur.
    • Midline Anomalies: Often seen in conjunction with other midline developmental issues.
    • Clinical Syndromes and Chromosomal Abnormalities: The malformation may be linked to various syndromes and chromosomal conditions, indicating a need for comprehensive evaluation.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

ALSO LEARN:

Chiari 1

Chiari 2

Chiari 3

questions.text: A patient presented with epilepsy and difficulty in walking. On undergoing an MRI, the following image was obtained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Arnold-Chiari malformations are a group of neurological disorders characterized by structural abnormalities in the cerebellum, brainstem, and spinal cord. They occur when part of the cerebellum, the lower part of the brain, extends downward into the spinal canal. This can put pressure on the spinal cord and other nearby structures.

Types of Arnold-Chiari Malformations

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Arnold Chiari Malformation is herniation of cerebellar tonsil through foramen Magnum.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option A: Dandy-Walker malformation is characterized by cystic dilatation of the fourth ventricle, enlarged posterior fossa and hypoplasia of cerebellar vermis

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented with a history of seizures and forgetfulness. On undergoing an MRI, the following image was obtained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Glioblastoma is characterized by its aggressive nature, heterogeneous imaging features, and significant surrounding edema.

Imaging Techniques

  • MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): The primary modality used for diagnosis and monitoring.

Imaging Findings

  1. Tumor Appearance:
    • Location: Often found in the cerebral hemispheres, particularly in the frontal and temporal lobes.
    • Size: Typically, large and may be infiltrative.
    • Shape: Irregular and heterogeneous
  2. Signal Characteristics:
    • T1-weighted Images: Usually hypointense compared to normal brain tissue.
    • T2-weighted/FLAIR Images: Often hyperintense with associated edema.
    • Contrast Enhancement: Marked enhancement after administration of contrast, often with a surrounding ring of edema.
  3. Associated Features:
    • Mass Effect: Displacement of midline structures.
    • Ventricular Compression: Possible due to the tumor's mass effect.
    • Necrosis: Central necrosis may be present, contributing to heterogeneous enhancement.
  4. Diffusion-Weighted Imaging (DWI):
    • May show restricted diffusion in areas of high cellularity.
  5. Perfusion Imaging:
    • Increased cerebral blood volume (CBV) can be indicative of high-grade tumors.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Glioblastomas multiforme is a brain tumor involving the cerebral hemisphere that gives the appearance of a butterfly, also known as butterfly tumor.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option A: Meningioma is an extra-axial tumor and is seen with broad base towards the dura and Dural tail sign.

Option C: Pituitary macroadenoma extends beyond Sella through the diaphragma selli that produces a characteristic constriction in the middle and gives an appearance of Snowman figure/ Figure of 8. Due to its mass effect occurs Bitemporal Hemianopia.

Option D: Bilateral Vestibular Schwannoma is a tumor of vestibular nerves and is a hallmark feature in Neurofibromatosis type 2. It is located at cerebello-pontine angle. Radiologically seen as Ice cream cone appearance on MRI.

questions.text: A patient came to OPD with complains of vision problems. On doing an examination it was found to be Bitemporal Hemianopia. He/She was advised to undergo an MRI examination which is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A pituitary macroadenoma is a benign tumor larger than 10 mm that arises from the pituitary gland. It can lead to various clinical symptoms due to hormone overproduction or compression of surrounding structures.

Clinical Presentation

  • Hormonal Effects: Depending on the type of adenoma, symptoms can include:
    • Prolactinoma: Galactorrhea, amenorrhea, infertility.
    • Growth Hormone Adenoma: Acromegaly, gigantism.
    • Corticotropin Adenoma: Cushing's disease.
  • Mass Effects: Headaches, visual disturbances (particularly bitemporal hemianopia due to optic chiasm compression).

Radiology

  • Imaging Modality: MRI is the preferred method for diagnosing pituitary macroadenomas.
    • Signal Characteristics: On T1-weighted images, macroadenomas typically appear isointense to hypointense, while they may show variable signal intensity on T2-weighted images.
    • Enhancement: After contrast administration, they usually show enhancement due to their vascularity.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Tumor size of less than 1 cm is considered as microadenoma and of more than 1 cm is considered as macro adenoma.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option D: Pinealoma is a tumor of Pineal gland. It can cause Parinaud syndrome due to compression of tectum leading to vertical gaze palsy; obstructive hydrocephalus (compression of cerebral aqueduct); precocious puberty in males (β-hCG production).

Pineal gland

Pinealoma

Option A: Meningioma is a primary Benign tumor; it is an Extra-axial tumor (external to brain parenchyma) and may have a dural attachment which is the Dural Tail sign. Histologically Psammoma bodies are seen (lamellated calcifications).

Option B: Glioblastoma is a highly malignant tumor found in Cerebral hemispheres. It can cross corpus callosum giving rise to Butterfly pattern on imaging.

questions.text: A 5-year-old patient presented with history of weakness and altered gait. On doing an MRI the following image was obtained.
questions.solution:
Pilocytic astrocytoma's, also known as juvenile pilocytic astrocytoma, are circumscribed, low-grade gliomas predominantly found in children and young adults.

Clinical Features

  • Typically present with symptoms related to increased intracranial pressure, cerebellar dysfunction, or visual disturbances, especially when located near the optic pathways.

Imaging Modality

  • MRI is the preferred imaging technique for evaluating pilocytic astrocytoma.
    • Often contains a large cystic component with a mural nodule that enhances with contrast.
    • May show associated calcifications, but these are not always present.
    • Peritumoral edema is common and may be prominent, especially with larger tumors.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • WHO Grade 1 tumor.
  • Epidemiology: Most common primary brain tumor in childhood (approximately 15%) and the second most common pediatric posterior fossa tumor (about 30%), following medulloblastomas.

Histopathology Appearance of pilocytic astrocytoma contains Rosenthal fibers(eosinophilic corkscrew fibers).

OTHER OTIONS:

Option A: Hemangioblastoma, a tumor with blood vessel origin with thin-walled capillaries closely arranged with minimal intervening parenchyma. A Cerebellar tumor.

Option D: Oligodendroglioma, usually located in frontal region; often calcified. Histologically cells are of Fried egg appearance and capillaries are seen in Chicken wire pattern.

questions.text: Given below is a DTI image of MRI brain. Identify the structure marked in the image below.
questions.solution:
KEY TAKE AWAY:

Visual pathway

questions.text: A patient presented with hemifacial numbness and tingling sensation. On doing an MRI examination trigeminal schwannoma was diagnosed. What is the structure marked in the image through which the trigeminal nerve passes?
questions.solution: KEY TAKE AWAY:

questions.text: A patient presented with gradual onset of deafness. On further investigation it was found to be of sensorineural type and was advised to undergo an MRI examination. The following image was obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is a rare autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder characterized by the development of multiple central nervous system (CNS) tumors. Here's a summary:

Overview

  • Genetics: NF2 is caused by mutations in the NF2 gene located on chromosome 22, which encodes the protein merlin.
  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominan

Clinical Presentation

  • Typical Age of Onset: Usually presents in young adults, typically between ages 18-24.
  • Common Tumors:
    • Vestibular Schwannomas (Acoustic Neuromas): Often bilateral and can lead to hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance issues.
    • Meningiomas: Can be located intracranially or in the spinal canal.
    • Ependymomas: Frequently found in the spinal cord.

Symptoms

  • Hearing loss, balance difficulties, headaches, and neurological deficits, depending on the location and size of tumors.

Imaging Modality: MRI is the preferred method for evaluating CNS tumors associated with NF2 due to its superior soft tissue contrast.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Key Findings

  1. Bilateral Vestibular Schwannomas (Acoustic Neuromas):
    • Typically arise at the cerebellopontine angle.
    • Appearance:
      • On T1-weighted images: Isointense to hypointense relative to brain tissue.
      • On T2-weighted images: Hyperintense.
      • Often show enhancement after contrast administration.
  2. Meningiomas:
    • Location: Can occur in various intracranial and spinal locations.
    • Appearance:
      • Isointense or hyperintense on T2-weighted images.
      • Typically show strong homogeneous enhancement post-contrast.
      • Often associated with hyperostosis of the adjacent bone.
  3. Ependymomas:
    • Location: Frequently located in the spinal canal, especially in the cervical and lumbar regions.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option C: Von Hippel Lindau disease is an Autosomal Dominant disorder with deletion of VHL gene on chromosome 3p. It characterized by Hemangioblastoma, Capillary hemangiomas, Renal cell carcinomas and Pheochromocytomas.

Option D: Tuberous sclerosis is an Autosomal Dominant disorder with TSC1 gene(hamartin) mutation on chromosome 9 and TSC2 (tuberin) mutation on chromosome 16.

questions.text: A young patient presented with seizures. On physical examination, port wine stain was seen on the face. What could be the expected finding on doing a CT scan of brain?
questions.solution:
Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS), also known as encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis, is a neurocutaneous disorder characterized by facial port-wine nevus and pial angiomas. It is primarily associated with the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve.

Key Features

Clinical Presentation

  • Facial Nevus: Congenital port-wine stain, often present at birth.
  • Neurological Symptoms: Seizures, developmental delays, and possible hemiparesis, particularly related to cortical involvement.

Radiological Findings

Plain Radiography

  • Gyriform Calcification: Typically becomes evident between ages 2-7.

CT Imaging

  • Subcortical Calcifications: Early identification of calcifications compared to plain films.
  • Tram-Track Sign: Represents cortical and subcortical calcifications.
  • Volume Loss: Associated parenchymal volume loss may be visible.
  • Enlargement: Calvarial and regional sinus enlargement may occur.
  • Choroid Plexus: Ipsilateral enlargement may be noted.
  • Dyke-Davidoff-Masson Appearance: In severe cases, this appearance indicates hemispheric atrophy.
  • Orbital Choroidal Hemangiomas: May be present.
  • Cavernous Sinus: Asymmetric enlargement may be evident.

MRI Findings

  • T1-weighted Images:
    • Generally normal signal in the affected region, with volume loss evident at older ages.
    • Gadolinium Enhancement: Prominent leptomeningeal enhancement due to venous congestion and ischemia.
  • T2-weighted Images:
    • Low signal in white matter subjacent to the angioma, possibly indicating accelerated myelination in neonates.
    • Later calcification may be present.
    • Abnormal Venous Drainage: Flow voids may be seen.
  • Advanced Techniques:
    • Gradient Echo (GE)/Susceptibility Weighted Imaging (SWI): Sensitive to calcifications, showing regions of signal dropout.
    • MR Spectroscopy: Typically shows decreased N-acetyl aspartate (NAA), indicating neuronal loss.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of throbbing headache and blurring of vision. On doing a CT scan and angiogram of the brain, the following image was obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Brain arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) are high-flow vascular malformations characterized by a complex tangle of blood vessels that includes enlarged feeding arteries, a nidus where arteriovenous shunting occurs, and draining veins. They are the most common symptomatic vascular malformations of the brain.

Clinical Presentation

AVMs can present in various ways:

  • Incidental Finding: Detected in asymptomatic patients (15%).
  • Seizures: Occur in about 20% of patients.
  • Headaches: Common complaint.
  • Focal Neurological Deficits: Observed in approximately 15%.
  • Hemorrhage: The most common presentation, occurring in about 65% of cases, with an annual incidence of 2-3%. Hemorrhage can manifest as:
    • Parenchymal
    • Subarachnoid
    • Intraventricular

Diagnosis

Non-Contrast CT

  • Difficulties: Identifying an AVM can be challenging on non-contrast CT.
  • Appearance: The nidus may be hyperdense compared to adjacent brain tissue, and enlarged draining veins may be visible. However, large AVMs usually do not exert mass effect unless they bleed.

Contrast-Enhanced Imaging

  • CT Angiography (CTA): After contrast administration, the AVM becomes more apparent, revealing the characteristic "bag of worms" appearance with visible feeding arteries, draining veins, and the nidus.
  • Limitations: While CTA provides valuable information, it may not clearly delineate the exact anatomy of feeding and draining vessels, making conventional angiography necessary.

Angiography (Digital Subtraction Angiography - DSA)

  • Gold Standard: Cerebral angiography remains the definitive method for evaluating AVMs.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Brain AVM are high flow, vascular malformation.
  • Investigations like NCCT, CECT angiography can be used for diagnosis, but gold standard remains DSA, digital subtraction, angiography.

questions.text: A patient presented with loss of coordination, difficulty in speech and vertigo. He also complains of visual disturbances, headache and palpitations. On doing an MRI, a space occupying lesion is noted in the cerebellum as shown below. What would be the expected finding in the kidneys?
questions.solution:
Von Hippel-Lindau disease is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of various benign and malignant tumors due to mutations in the VHL tumor suppressor gene located on chromosome 3. It affects multiple organ systems, leading to a wide range of clinical manifestations.

Key Tumor Types and Locations

Abdominopelvic Region

  1. Renal:
    • Renal Cell Carcinomas (RCCs):
      • Occur in over 67% of patients.
      • Typically, of the clear cell type and often bilateral.
    • Renal Cysts:
      • Present in up to 75% of patients, often bilateral and multiple.
      • Can be simple or complex, with potential for cystic RCC.
    • Renal Angiomyolipoma: Benign tumors that may also develop.
  2. Adrenal:
    • Pheochromocytomas: Found in 25-30% of patients. Accounts for palpitations and headache in the history given above. other important features are episodic hypertension and orthostatic hypotension.
    • Extra-adrenal Pheochromocytomas/Paragangliomas
  3. Pancreas:
    • Pancreatic Cysts: Approximately 40% of patients may have these.
    • Pancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumors (pNET)
    • Pancreatic Serous Cystadenomas
    • Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma: Rarely seen.
  4. Liver:
    • Liver cysts may develop.
  5. Lung:
    • Lung cysts and carcinoid tumors can occur.

Urogenital System

  • Epididymal Cysts: Present in many patients.
  • Papillary Cystadenoma of the Epididymis
  • Broad Ligament Cystadenomas.

Central Nervous System (CNS)

  • CNS Hemangioblastomas: Found in about 70% of patients.
    • Commonly located in the cerebellum (60%) and spinal cord (30%), particularly cervical and thoracic regions.
  • Choroid Plexus Papilloma: May occur.

Head and Neck

  • Retinal Hemangioblastomas:
    • The most common presenting feature, seen in 45-60% of patients, can lead to vision loss.
  • Endolymphatic Sac Tumors (ELST): Present in 10-15% of patients and bilateral in 30%, considered pathognomonic for vHL.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Option D: Chromophobe RCC is associated with Birt-Hogg-Dube Syndrome.
